title: Electron Microscopy of Transformation Induces Lattice Distortions in TiHfZrNb0.3 Refractory High Entropy Alloys
content: Refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) are a subset of high entropy alloys (HEAs) composed primarily of refractory metals such as niobium, molybdenum, tantalum, titanium, hafnium [1]. These alloys have attracted considerable interest for their remarkable ability to maintain strength at high temperatures [2]. However, only a few RHEA compositions are known to exhibit significant strain resistance exceeding 10% at room temperature. TiHfZrNbx is one example [3]. With Nb in non-equimolar proportions, this alloy can improve the ductility with the hexagonal close-packed (HCP) phase transformation-induced plasticity (TRIP) [4]. This alloy also has a high density of fine ω particles that are often observed in conventional Ti alloys. However, the role of hexagonal ω phase in ductility is not clear.
